topics.body:
I find the squeamishness about showing an organ 50 percent of the human population possesses hilarious personally.

Ok fine, I see no problem with not wanting naughty bits in stuff meant for family viewing. But if you're making a film for adults anyways then who the fuck cares about the amount of dicks, pussies and tits or what state they're in? It isn't like they'd be showing me anything I haven't seen before.

topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538f7c986368721d87a90200#post_538f7c986368721d87a90200
Must be easier than the mammoth right? They should have more tissues of the birds, as well the fact that birds mature faster than elephants.
topics.author: 4fded3ad945b700aaa01381d

topics.body:
"@Grieffon":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538f7d406368721b647d0300#post_538f7d406368721b647d0300
Yes. However, the mammoth project is actually in progress already (or at least a mammoth-elephant hybrid, geneticist George Church has already transferred three mammoth gene variants into elephant cells and could have an embryo in three years).

Ben Novak is already sequencing DNA from passenger pigeon specimens in museums. He hopes to publish an update by September, the 100th anniversary of its extinction.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538f7db76368721bfe970200#post_538f7db76368721bfe970200
By the way, why did they start with the mammoth? Shouldn't they start with something easier to revive, like the passenger pigeon?
topics.author: 4fded3ad945b700aaa01381d

topics.body:
"@Grieffon":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538f7e6d6368721c13ed0300#post_538f7e6d6368721c13ed0300
I have no idea. But they started it anyway.

Once the DNA has been sequenced from the pigeon, they want to start culturing germ cells from modern band-tailed pigeons, which make eggs and sperm, synthesize the passenger pigeon DNA, and edit the genomes of the germ cells to contain the new passenger pigeon DNA. Then they will put the germ cells into band-tailed pigeon embryos devoid of their own, wait for the band-tailed pigeons to hatch, grow up, mate, and lay eggs, which will hopefully hatch into band-tailed/passenger pigeon hybrids.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097
